trans-unit.source: Stream Analytics: Rotate log-in credentials for inputs and outputs | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Stream Analytics: Rotate log-in credentials for inputs and outputs | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to update the credentials for Stream Analytics inputs and outputs.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to update the credentials for Stream Analytics inputs and outputs.

trans-unit.source: Azure Stream Analytics today doesn’t allow replacing the credentials on an input/output while the job is running.
trans-unit.target: Azure Stream Analytics today doesn’t allow replacing the credentials on an input/output while the job is running.

trans-unit.source: While Azure Stream Analytics does support resuming a job from last output, we wanted to share the entire process for minimizing the lag between the stopping and starting of the job.
trans-unit.target: While Azure Stream Analytics does support resuming a job from last output, we wanted to share the entire process for minimizing the lag between the stopping and starting of the job.

trans-unit.source: This part is applicable to the following inputs/outputs:
trans-unit.target: This part is applicable to the following inputs/outputs:

trans-unit.source: For other inputs/outputs, proceed with Part 2.
trans-unit.target: For other inputs/outputs, proceed with Part 2.

trans-unit.source: Go to the Storage extention on the Azure Management Portal: <linkText>graphic1</linkText>
trans-unit.target: Go to the Storage extention on the Azure Management Portal: <linkText>graphic1</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Locate the storage used by your job and go into it: <linkText>graphic2</linkText>
trans-unit.target: Locate the storage used by your job and go into it: <linkText>graphic2</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click the Manage Access Keys command: <linkText>graphic3</linkText>
trans-unit.target: Click the Manage Access Keys command: <linkText>graphic3</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Between the Primary Access Key and the Secondary Access Key, pick the one not used by your job.
trans-unit.target: Between the Primary Access Key and the Secondary Access Key, pick the one not used by your job.

trans-unit.source: Go to the Service Bus extension on the Azure Management Portal: <linkText>graphic6</linkText>
trans-unit.target: Go to the Service Bus extension on the Azure Management Portal: <linkText>graphic6</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Locate the Service Bus Namespace used by your job and go into it: <linkText>graphic7</linkText>
trans-unit.target: Locate the Service Bus Namespace used by your job and go into it: <linkText>graphic7</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If your job uses a shared access policy on the Service Bus Namespace, jump to step 6
trans-unit.target: If your job uses a shared access policy on the Service Bus Namespace, jump to step 6

trans-unit.source: Go to the Event Hubs tab: <linkText>graphic8</linkText>
trans-unit.target: Go to the Event Hubs tab: <linkText>graphic8</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Locate the Event Hub used by your job and go into it: <linkText>graphic9</linkText>
trans-unit.target: Locate the Event Hub used by your job and go into it: <linkText>graphic9</linkText>

trans-unit.source: On the Policy Name drop-down, locate the shared access policy used by your job: <linkText>graphic11</linkText>
trans-unit.target: On the Policy Name drop-down, locate the shared access policy used by your job: <linkText>graphic11</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Between the Primary Key and the Secondary Key, pick the one not used by your job.
trans-unit.target: Between the Primary Key and the Secondary Key, pick the one not used by your job.

trans-unit.source: Note: you will need to connect to the SQL Databse Service.
trans-unit.target: Note: you will need to connect to the SQL Databse Service.

trans-unit.source: We are going to show how to do this using the management experience on the Azure Management Portal but you may choose to use some client-side tool such as SQL Server Management Studio as well.
trans-unit.target: We are going to show how to do this using the management experience on the Azure Management Portal but you may choose to use some client-side tool such as SQL Server Management Studio as well.

trans-unit.source: Go to the SQL Databases extension on the Azure Management Portal: <linkText>graphic14</linkText>
trans-unit.target: Go to the SQL Databases extension on the Azure Management Portal: <linkText>graphic14</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Locate the SQL Database used by your job and click on the server link on the same line: graphic15
trans-unit.target: Locate the SQL Database used by your job and click on the server link on the same line: graphic15

trans-unit.source: Type in your User Name, Password and click Log on: <linkText>graphic18</linkText>
trans-unit.target: Type in your User Name, Password and click Log on: <linkText>graphic18</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Type in the following query replacing with your User Name and replacing with your new password: CREATE LOGIN WITH PASSWORD = ''
trans-unit.target: Type in the following query replacing with your User Name and replacing with your new password: CREATE LOGIN WITH PASSWORD = ''

trans-unit.source: Go back to step 2 and this time click the database: <linkText>graphic21</linkText>
trans-unit.target: Go back to step 2 and this time click the database: <linkText>graphic21</linkText>

trans-unit.source: type in your User Name, Password, and click Log on: <linkText>graphic23</linkText>
trans-unit.target: type in your User Name, Password, and click Log on: <linkText>graphic23</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Type in the following query replacing name> with a name by which you want to identify this login in the context of this database (you can provide the same value you gave for name>, for example) and replacing with your new user name: CREATE USER FROM LOGIN
trans-unit.target: Type in the following query replacing name> with a name by which you want to identify this login in the context of this database (you can provide the same value you gave for name>, for example) and replacing with your new user name: CREATE USER FROM LOGIN

trans-unit.source: You should now provide your new user with the same roles and privledges your original user had.
trans-unit.target: You should now provide your new user with the same roles and privledges your original user had.

trans-unit.source: Go to the Stream Analytics extension on the Azure Management Portal: <linkText>graphic26</linkText>
trans-unit.target: Go to the Stream Analytics extension on the Azure Management Portal: <linkText>graphic26</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Locate your job and go into it: <linkText>graphic27</linkText>
trans-unit.target: Locate your job and go into it: <linkText>graphic27</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Go to the Inputs tab or the Outputs tab based on whether you are rotating the credentials on an Input or on an Output.
trans-unit.target: Go to the Inputs tab or the Outputs tab based on whether you are rotating the credentials on an Input or on an Output.

trans-unit.source: Click the Stop command and confirm the job has stopped: <linkText>graphic29</linkText> Wait for the job to stop.
trans-unit.target: Click the Stop command and confirm the job has stopped: <linkText>graphic29</linkText> Wait for the job to stop.

trans-unit.source: Locate the input/output you want to rotate credentials on and go into it: <linkText>graphic30</linkText>
trans-unit.target: Locate the input/output you want to rotate credentials on and go into it: <linkText>graphic30</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Find the Storage Account Key field and paste your newly generated key into it: <linkText>graphic31</linkText>
trans-unit.target: Find the Storage Account Key field and paste your newly generated key into it: <linkText>graphic31</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click the Save command and confirm saving your changes: <linkText>graphic32</linkText>
trans-unit.target: Click the Save command and confirm saving your changes: <linkText>graphic32</linkText>

trans-unit.source: A connection test will automatically start when you save your changes, make sure that is has successfully passed.
trans-unit.target: A connection test will automatically start when you save your changes, make sure that is has successfully passed.

trans-unit.source: Find the Event Hub Policy Key field and paste your newly generated key into it: <linkText>graphic33</linkText>
trans-unit.target: Find the Event Hub Policy Key field and paste your newly generated key into it: <linkText>graphic33</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click the Save command and confirm saving your changes: <linkText>graphic34</linkText>
trans-unit.target: Click the Save command and confirm saving your changes: <linkText>graphic34</linkText>

trans-unit.source: A connection test will automatically start when you save your changes, make sure that it has successfully passed.
trans-unit.target: A connection test will automatically start when you save your changes, make sure that it has successfully passed.

trans-unit.source: You will get the following confirmation:
trans-unit.target: You will get the following confirmation:

trans-unit.source: Click the Save command and confirm saving your changes: <linkText>graphic37</linkText>
trans-unit.target: Click the Save command and confirm saving your changes: <linkText>graphic37</linkText>

trans-unit.source: A connection test will automatically start when you save your changes, make sure it has successfully passed.
trans-unit.target: A connection test will automatically start when you save your changes, make sure it has successfully passed.

trans-unit.source: Find the User Name and Password fields and paste your newly created set of credentials into them: <linkText>graphic38</linkText>
trans-unit.target: Find the User Name and Password fields and paste your newly created set of credentials into them: <linkText>graphic38</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click the Save command and confirm saving your changes: <linkText>graphic39</linkText>
trans-unit.target: Click the Save command and confirm saving your changes: <linkText>graphic39</linkText>

trans-unit.source: A connection test will automatically start when you save your changes, make sure that it has successfully passed.
trans-unit.target: A connection test will automatically start when you save your changes, make sure that it has successfully passed.

trans-unit.source: Pick the Last Stopped Time and click OK: <linkText>graphic42</linkText>
trans-unit.target: Pick the Last Stopped Time and click OK: <linkText>graphic42</linkText>

trans-unit.source: This part is applicable to the following inputs/outputs:
trans-unit.target: This part is applicable to the following inputs/outputs:

trans-unit.source: Repeat Part 1 for the Access Key that was previously used by your job to renew the now unused Access Key.
trans-unit.target: Repeat Part 1 for the Access Key that was previously used by your job to renew the now unused Access Key.

trans-unit.source: Repeat Part 1 for the Key that was previously used by your job to renew the now unused Key.
trans-unit.target: Repeat Part 1 for the Key that was previously used by your job to renew the now unused Key.

trans-unit.source: Go back to the query window from Part 1 Step 7 and type in the following query, replacing loginname> with the User Name that was previously used by your job: DROP LOGIN
trans-unit.target: Go back to the query window from Part 1 Step 7 and type in the following query, replacing loginname> with the User Name that was previously used by your job: DROP LOGIN

trans-unit.source: You should get the following confirmation:
trans-unit.target: You should get the following confirmation:

trans-unit.source: For further assistance, try our <linkText>Azure Stream Analytics forum</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: For further assistance, try our <linkText>Azure Stream Analytics forum</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Stream Analytics Management REST API Reference</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Stream Analytics Management REST API Reference</linkText><title></title>
